ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed my academic reading skills, since many of the texts we read were at first impenetrably dense to me but made sense as the class progressed. I also will never see memes the same way, or any form of media for that matter - I know so much more about the function, creation, and spread of memes and since theyre everywhere, Ill be analyzing each one I see subconsciously.
I learned how to read and comprehend very dense, academic jargon filled articles and research papers.
I learned how to better speak in seminar setting and how to explain my thoughts more clearly.
Learned about lots of theoretical concepts related to aesthetics, media, human emotion, digital culture, etc. Learned how to analyze digital media using these theories.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course has a very interesting subject matter and premise, but the course frequently strayed from music, memes, or digital culture per se. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but at times, it felt insufficiently connected to the ultimate goal of understanding memes. This was exacerbated by the difficulty/esoteric nature of the readings. When we had the activities/time to really understand a reading, the class worked quite well, but when we didn't, I think most people didn't get much out of the readings. The extremely academic nature of some readings, with name dropping and references all over the place, made it difficult to engage.
Was nice because as long as you went to class, you did well. He understood we all had a lot of work so the workload was relatively low which was nice.

Overall this was a great course. I liked that Professor Shelley had us do a variety of activities such as debates and presentations to help us understand the readings better. The class discussions were interesting. Sometimes reading the introductions to different readings seemed a bit pointless, and maybe overall the readings could've been trimmed down a tiny bit.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, its really fun to apply academic concepts to everyday memes, and I learned a ton both about memes and about all forms of media in general.
I would recommend this course because it is both fun and intellectually challenging especially for students interested in things like music in relation to social media use today.
Yes I would, especially if taught by Professor Shelley. It is a great class and I think the small details/choices that Shelley adds to it made it an even better experience.
Yes I loved this course and the professor
Yes I would recommend for a student looking to take a different type of course and break away from weekly PSETs.
Yes! It was an interesting seminar.
